title: 105_hr569
content: Section 1 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to reduce the amount that a nonparty multicandidate political committee can contribute to a candidate in a congressional election to $1,000. Additionally, Section 2 imposes limitations on contributions from persons other than in-state individual residents in congressional elections. Section 315 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to restrict candidates for Congress from accepting contributions from out-of-state individuals that exceed contributions from in-state residents. Exceptions for small contributions are not applicable for these elections. The term 'in-State individual resident' is defined as an individual who resides in the state where the election takes place. SEC. 3 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to prohibit cash contributions exceeding $100. SEC. 4 prohibits independent expenditures within 7 days before a congressional election. SEC. 5 prohibits contributions between multicandidate political committees. SEC. 5 prohibits contributions between multicandidate political committees. SEC. 6 requires multicandidate political committees affiliated with other organizations to include the organization's name in their own name. SEC. 7 prohibits bundling. SEC. 7 prohibits bundling of contributions through intermediaries or conduits, allowing only facilitation of contributions through advice or mailing materials. SEC. 8 requires lobbyists making contributions to disclose their lobbyist status. SEC. 9 and SEC. 10 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 introduce reporting requirements for lobbyists and out-of-state contributions in House of Representatives elections. Lobbyists must disclose their status when making contributions, and report contributions to the Commission within 20 days. Section 304 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 now requires all reports of contributions for House of Representatives elections to segregate and itemize out-of-State contributions. Additionally, there is a ban on soft money. SEC. 11 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 prohibits the solicitation, receipt, or use of soft money for influencing federal elections. Soft money refers to funds from prohibited sources, exceeding contribution limits, or not subject to reporting requirements. The amendments made by this Act will apply to elections starting from the general election on November 5, 1998.
